Award.AwardTitle: A comparative and ethnographic study of Arabic language use

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Joel Kuipers of George Washington University proposes to explore the relationship between the usage of Arabic as a sacred speech register and emerging forms of religious identity. The project will test key hypotheses about how gender, education, urbanization, and rapid mediatization affect participation in Islam. The research will take place in Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim country. The role of classical Arabic (fussha) in everyday life has dramatically expanded in the last 30 years, evidenced in personal names, greetings, Qur'anic verses and other pious expressions in everyday life. At the same time, old patterns of piety are changing, reflected not only in new political alignments, but new ways of expressing faith, ways that are seldom examined by scholars. By focusing on the largest ethnic group in Indonesia - the Javanese - the research examines specifically the role of the Arabic language in the emerging realignment of pious identities in everyday life. Drawing on advanced methods in linguistic anthropology, the proposed study will collect and examine detailed transcriptions of recordings of everyday interactions, classrooms, prayer houses, popular films, radio talk shows, and a variety of other contexts in which pious subjectivities are displayed and evaluated. The results will not only demonstrate rigorous new linguistic methodologies for investigating religious subjectivity, but also provide substantive and comparative insights into patterns of piety in the world's fourth largest country. The project makes strong contributions to international collaboration among scientists through its affiliation with an Indonesian research team at Gadja Mada University. The project also supports the training of undergraduate and graduate students in anthropology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the world’s largest Muslim-majority country, Indonesia has been undergoing a religious revival. While the overall percentages of Muslims in Indonesian society has not changed, the intensity of religious identification and expression has shifted. But how to study this? This study demonstrates that a careful, systematic and comparative examination of the uses of the sacred language of Islam – Arabic – can provide crucial – and surprising - clues. Based on a study of 3.7 million names in Java - the largest ethnic group in Indonesia - it is clear that while Javanese parents are increasingly giving their children Arabic sounding names, they are also adding additional names so their children have Javanese and European sounding names as well. This means that while Arabic language names are increasing, the Javanese penchant for cultural synthesis and hybridity is alive and well.

            The study also looks at how Arabic is used by Javanese in everyday life. By recording, transcribing and analyzing the ways in which this sacred language is juxtaposed with other linguistic resources – Indonesian, Javanese and sometimes even English – it is possible to get a glimpse not only of the status of these languages in conversation, but also of the importance of doctrinal versus performative issues in social interaction.  Many commentators on Islam in the region have tended to see the central debate as one between secularist modernists or militant Islamists.  When analyzing the rich and relentless contestation of religious authority in Indonesia, however, it is crucial to recognize that what is at stake is not so much religious doctrine but expertise in religious practice.

The study reveals that the context of Arabic language education has been undergoing rapid change in the last 30 years. Islamic education in Indonesia, as in many Muslim majority countries, has often focused on the study and recitation of the Qur'an, and is sometimes described as unchanged since the "medieval period." However, as the Indonesian national education system grows and gradually increases capacity, it now increasingly serves populations that once resisted its services: Islamic schools, pesantren and madrasahs. Drawing on recordings, interviews, transcriptions and direct observation, I show that not only is the language used undergoing change (Javanese language instruction is increasingly now in Indonesian), but the styles of student teacher interaction in Arabic are changing in ways that reflect the shifting meanings of religious authority.

Finally, in this study, I show that Arabic plays a different role for boys and girls, and for men and women. For girls and women, using Arabic is a more personal, private, and intimately aesthetic and emotional experience than it is for men.  By comparing naming practices, school participation, and the phenomenon of kesurupan 'spirit possession,' I show that men and women come to inhabit different worlds, one emphasizing physical beauty, personal comportment, and emotional experience, while boys and men are guided toward uses of Arabic that privilege public spaces, communal performances, and externally oriented recognition and displays of status.  

There are several broader impacts of the study. During the period of the grant, one research assistant was able to complete his PhD on the basis of the project, two researchers were able to complete MA degrees, and another US based student was able to spend a year in Indonesia on an REU grant and now has successfully completed applications to PhD programs in the USA. The data collected have formed the basis of several articles, more than a dozen invited lectures, and a rough book manuscript which will be revised in the coming year. It has also resulted in a successful grant proposal to the PEER/USAID program for a 3 year research project on science education in Islamic schools.
